title: Single symbiotic cell transcriptome sequencing of coral
abstract: Zooxanthellae and coral can form an intracellular symbiotic system. Yet, little is known about the molecular mechanism underlying this symbiosis. In this study, we characterized the symbiosis based on analyses of gene expression at the single-cell level. Among 9110 single coral cells, we identified 4871 symbiotic cells based on the detection of both coral and zooxanthellae gene transcripts within a single cell. Using the bioinformatics tool Seurat, symbiotic cells were further clustered into five groups, 52 genes exhibited differential expression between groups. We proposed an index called the "symbiosis index", to indicate the degree of gene expression of both species in a single symbiotic cell. Interestingly, the index differed distinctly among the five groups. The symbiosis index was highly correlated with the expression of the coral gene gfas1.m1.6761 (ANKRD40), which encodes ankyrin repeat domain-containing protein 40 and is involved in DNA replication (r = 0.76). Two metabolismrelated genes, DAGLA and betaGlu, were highly expressed in cells with a high symbiosis index. Four zooxanthellae genes, PRPF19, ATRN, aAA-ATPases and AK812-SmicGene44833, exhibited substantial changes in expression levels when zooxanthellae lived within coral. A trajectory analysis suggested that cells with a higher symbiosis index may be derived from those with a lower index during coral colony development. Taken together, our results provide evidence for zooxanthellae residing within coral, forming a symbiotic system. The symbiosis index is an effective indicator of different cell groups, with lineage relationships among groups. Additionally, we identified specific genes that exhibit expression changes in the symbiotic system.

abstract.text: Zooxanthellae and coral can form an intracellular symbiotic system. Yet, little is known about the molecular mechanism underlying this symbiosis. In this study, we characterized the symbiosis based on analyses of gene expression at the single-cell level. Among 9110 single coral cells, we identified 4871 symbiotic cells based on the detection of both coral and zooxanthellae gene transcripts within a single cell. Using the bioinformatics tool Seurat, symbiotic cells were further clustered into five groups, 52 genes exhibited differential expression between groups. We proposed an index called the "symbiosis index", to indicate the degree of gene expression of both species in a single symbiotic cell. Interestingly, the index differed distinctly among the five groups. The symbiosis index was highly correlated with the expression of the coral gene gfas1.m1.6761 (ANKRD40), which encodes ankyrin repeat domain-containing protein 40 and is involved in DNA replication (r = 0.76). Two metabolismrelated genes, DAGLA and betaGlu, were highly expressed in cells with a high symbiosis index. Four zooxanthellae genes, PRPF19, ATRN, aAA-ATPases and AK812-SmicGene44833, exhibited substantial changes in expression levels when zooxanthellae lived within coral. A trajectory analysis suggested that cells with a higher symbiosis index may be derived from those with a lower index during coral colony development. Taken together, our results provide evidence for zooxanthellae residing within coral, forming a symbiotic system. The symbiosis index is an effective indicator of different cell groups, with lineage relationships among groups. Additionally, we identified specific genes that exhibit expression changes in the symbiotic system.

body_text.text: Corals are referred to as tropical rainforests in the oceans, providing a habitat to fishes and contributing to ocean biodiversity [1, 2] . Coral is not able to survive without intracellular symbiotic zooxanthellae, which provide organic photosynthetic products [3] . However, zooxanthellae can live independently, without coral. This symbiotic relationship, with a one way benefit, is an interesting phenomenon and has attracted substantial attention in biological research [4, 5] . Histological evidence has shown that zooxanthellae mainly reside in the oral endoderm cells of coral [3, 6] . Zooxanthellae can provide some essential amino acids to the host, while the host has lost the ability to synthesize some amino acids [7] [8] [9] [10] [11] . Additional microorganisms have also been found in the coral cells along with zooxanthellae [12, 13] . Despite these advances, we still know little about the molecular mechanism underlying the symbiosis, especially at the single-cell level. How do single symbiotic cells differ from free-living cells? Can molecular markers be used as indicators of the symbiotic state? To resolve these issues, single-cell analyses are needed.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: We used single-cell sequencing to compare the gene expression profiles at the single-cell level. This approach is widely used in studies of stem cells and cancer cells [14] . Coral is a unique cnidarian. Its whole polyp body is made of only two layers, endoderm and ectoderm, connected by an extracellular matrix called the mesoglea [15] . Importantly, coral is an intracellular symbiotic animal, meaning that both zooxanthellae and coral genomes coexist in a single coral cell. Single-cell sequencing can provide information for the two genomes simultaneously and could be used to identify symbiotic features.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: In this study, we used single-cell transcriptomic sequencing technology (RNA-Seq) to investigate the symbiotic relationship between coral and zooxanthellae. We successfully captured 9110 coral cells and identified 4871 symbiotic cells. We clustered the cells and identified highly expressed and differentially expressed genes. We also proposed an indicator, the symbiosis index, of gene expression in symbiotic cells. Our results provide a new insight to the coral.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The calcium-free artificial seawater dissociation method was used to harvest cells [16, 17] . A single-cell suspension was loaded onto a microwell array (Fig. 1 ). Microbeads with a unique cell barcode and unique molecular index (UMI) were then loaded on the microchip to ensure that each cell couples with a single bead. Cell lysis buffer was added and the microchip was incubated at 25 • C for cell lysis. The mRNAs for each cell were captured by microbeads upon cell lysis. The microbeads were then transferred from the microchip to a single tube for reverse transcription and library construction [18] . The cDNA was synthesized via reverse transcription and amplified by PCR. A single-cell sequencing library was constructed by fragmenting the double-strained cDNA and ligating adapters for the Illumina sequencing platform. The library was sequenced on the Illumina HiSeq X platform to obtain 150bp paired-end reads.
body_text.section: Single coral cell harvesting and sequencing

body_text.text: We evaluated the expression of coral and zooxanthellae genes at the single-cell level. We obtained 7.97 M uniquely mapped reads (27.7% of total reads) for coral. We detected 9110 single cells. Each cell had at least one expressed gene. In more than half of the cells (n = 4871), we detected the expression of both coral and zooxanthellae genes, indicating that each of the cells contained transcripts from both species. This pattern provides evidence for a symbiotic relationship. In other cells, genes of either coral or zooxanthellae were expressed ( Fig. 2A ). The 9110 cells were divided into three types, Coral+Zoox, Coral only, and Zoox only. In the Coral+Zoox group (4871 cells), genes of both species were expressed in a single cell. In the other two types, either coral or zooxanthellae were expressed in a single cell.
body_text.section: Coral and zooxanthellae genes were both expressed in symbiotic cells

body_text.text: Gene expression was represented by UMI. Genes with more than one non-zero UMI were retained. In total, 10,335 genes were detected, of which 6661 were from coral and 3674 were from zooxanthellae. The Coral+Zoox cells had the highest UMI values, which were higher than those of Coral only and Zoox only cells (Fig. 2B ). The expression data showed substantial sparsity. Only about ten genes were expressed in more than 20% of cells (Fig. 2C) . The expression profiles for the three cell types are shown in Fig. 2D . It is important to note that sparsity is a basic characteristic of single-cell RNA-seq data, and some expressed genes are not identified due to dropout events.
body_text.section: Coral and zooxanthellae genes were both expressed in symbiotic cells

body_text.text: In short, we successfully captured coral cells and found that some of these cells indeed contain zooxanthellae. We detected zooxanthellae transcripts in coral cells. These results provide evidence for the symbiotic relationship between the species.
body_text.section: Coral and zooxanthellae genes were both expressed in symbiotic cells

body_text.text: To evaluate the unique characteristics of symbiotic cells (Coral+ Zoox), we performed a clustering analysis using the R package Seurat. The raw code for the analysis is provided in a supplementary file (Supp.1). We removed low-quality cells, defined as cells in which the number of the expressed genes are below 5% of the total genes, resulting in an expression matrix of 73 genes and 1368 cells.
body_text.section: Clustering of the single symbiotic cells

body_text.text: The cells were clustered into five distinct groups (referred to as G1-G5) (Fig. 3A) , with differences in gene expression profiles. Fifty-two differentially expressed genes (DEGs) were identified in one-to-others comparisons of the five groups (Table S1 ). The expression levels of the top 30 DEGs in the five groups are shown in Fig. 3B . The number of DEGs in each pairwise comparison is shown in Fig. 3C . Group G2 had the most DEGs (Fig. 3C ). Most genes were expressed at low levels in group G1 and at high levels in group G2. In the hierarchical tree based on Euclidean distances between groups G1 and G5 were closely related, and G2 was highly distinct from the other groups ( Fig. 3D ). These results showed that symbiotic cells exhibited distinct gene expression profiles.
body_text.section: Clustering of the single symbiotic cells

body_text.text: To identify essential differences in symbiotic cells, we proposed an index called the symbiosis index to indicate the degree of gene expression of both species in a single cell. For a symbiotic cell, defining P Coral and P Zoox as the number of expressed genes relative to the total genes (expressed as percentages) for coral and zooxanthellae, respectively, the symbiosis index is defined as the product (log 10 (P Coral × P Zoox )). If the two species express their genes actively, the two percentages will approach 1.0, leading to a high product. Otherwise, the product of the two percentages will be low.
body_text.section: Symbiosis index in the symbiotic cells

body_text.text: Interestingly, we found differences in the symbiosis indices among the five groups ( Fig. 4A ). Group G2 had the highest symbiosis index, more than 80% of cells had a symbiosis index over − 3.6. In the other groups, the fraction of the cells with values exceeding − 3.6 was <25% (Fig. 4A ). Group G1 had the lowest symbiosis index. We further calculated Pearson correlation coefficients (r) for the relationship between gene expressions in cells of different groups. As expected, the intergroup correlation was weaker than the intra-group correlation ( Fig. 4B ), consistent with the clustering results. Unlike other groups, group G2 had high intra-group variation in correlation coefficients ( Fig. 4B ), indicating high heterogeneity in this group. Therefore, cells in this group had more variation in gene expression patterns, resulting in a low similarity between cells. In contrast, group G1 showed high intragroup similarity (Fig. 4B ). We inferred that most of cells assigned to G1 were not actively expressed since they had a very low symbiosis index.
body_text.section: Symbiosis index in the symbiotic cells

body_text.text: Briefly, our results revealed that gene expression differs in symbiotic cells. The newly defined symbiosis index effectively captured this difference. We investigated the association between the symbiosis index and expression of individual genes. The symbiosis index was highly correlated with the expression of the coral genes gfas1.m1.6761 (ANKRD40) (r = 0.76) ( Fig. 4C) . Accordingly, the expression of ANKRD40 is a potential indicator of the symbiosis index. ANKRD40 encodes ankyrin repeat domain-containing protein 40 [19] , which is functionally linked to RCF3, involved in DNA replication (from the String database, https://version11.string-db.org/cgi/network.pl? taskId=YrZEUaVaqumz). We also identified DEGs between cells with high and low symbiosis index values (Fig. 4D ). As expected, ANKRD40 was among the top upregulated genes in cells with a high symbiosis index. DAGLA and gfas1.m1.2339 (betaGlu) also showed high expression in these cells (Fig. 4D) . DAGLA encodes Sn1-specific diacylglycerol lipase alpha [20] . Additionally, gfas1.m1.2339, which encodes betaglucuronidase-like isoform X1 [21] , also associates to symbiosis index. The two genes are associated with metabolism.
body_text.section: Symbiosis index in the symbiotic cells

body_text.text: Clustering analyses can be used to separate cells into heterogeneous groups, without complete information about complex biological and regulatory processes. We performed a pseudo-time analysis of the symbiotic cells using the Monocle tool (Supp.1). By utilizing the asynchronous progression of biological processes, individual cells were placed along trajectories in pseudo-time.
body_text.section: Trajectory analysis for the five groups of symbiotic cells

body_text.text: In the trajectory plot, cells with a high symbiosis index (Group G2) were mainly detected at one end of the trajectory, while those with a low symbiosis index were mixed (Fig. 5) . With a low symbiosis index, cells in group G1 were scattered in all trajectories, suggested that G1 represents an initial state. G3, G4 and G5 showed similar pseudotime results, as their intra-group distances in trajectories were much closer than those of either G1 or G2 (Fig. 5 ). Cells of group G2 were located together in the trajectory plane. These patterns may suggest that cells with a relatively high symbiosis index would be inherited from cells with low values.
body_text.section: Trajectory analysis for the five groups of symbiotic cells

body_text.text: We identified DEGs between the symbiotic cells (Coral+Zoox, also referred to as Both) and non-symbiotic cells (Coral only and Zoox only) by the Wilcoxon rank sum test (Supp.1). The low p-value in this analysis ( Fig. 6 A and C) could be explained by two factors: the use of a nonparametric test and the sparsity of gene expression. Expression fold changes (log2) were mostly above 0 ( Fig. 6 B and D) , indicating that gene expression levels are higher in symbiotic cells than in Coral-only or in Zoox-only cells. The genes gfas1.m1.5324, 7220 and 1567 showed higher expression levels in the symbiotic cells (Coral+Zoox) than in Coral only cells (Table S2) . PRPF19, involved in cell survival and DNA repair [22] , showed a higher expression level in symbiotic cells than in zooxanthellae. ATRN, which encodes both membrane-bound and secreted protein isoforms [23] , showed significantly lower expression in symbiotic cells than in zooxanthellae. Two genes, AK812_Smic-Gene39669 (aAA-ATPase) and AK812-SmicGene44833 (Putative elongation of fatty acids protein) [24, 25] , were expressed at low levels in symbiotic cells (Table S3 ). These results suggested that some zooxanthellae genes exhibit expression changes in coral cells.
body_text.section: Comparison of gene expression between symbiotic and non-symbiotic cells

body_text.text: No permanent coral cell lineage has been established to date. Accordingly, primary cells were used for single-cell transcriptome sequencing in our study. To harvest high-quality coral cells for deposition on microwells, we applied two methods, enzyme digestion and calcium-free seawater dissociation methods. The latter method was more efficient for cell recovery, and was therefore used for subsequent single-cell separation [16] . However, some large multicellular endothelial isolates detach from the mother branch; we used a 40-μm filter to remove these large bulks. The viscous mucus secreted by the coral polyp was also filtered.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: We highlight three key contributions of this study. First, we demonstrated the first use of single-cell transcriptome sequencing of reef-building coral, especially in symbionts composed of both coral and zooxanthellae. Since the first report of a single-cell transcriptome sequencing technique about 10 years ago, continuous improvements have increased the capacity for processing cells by microfluidic and microporous technologies. This has resulted in major research advances, such as the single-cell transcriptome sequencing of the human neuron, kidney, breast cancer, retinal ganglion, and intestinal epithelium [26] [27] [28] [29] [30] . However, these studies have mainly focused on mammalian cells, which only contain a single genome. Single-cell transcriptome sequencing has not been applied to reef-building corals. Bertucci et al. compared coral gene expression between day and night and discovered a number of DEGs [31] . Ruiz-Jones et al. compared the transcriptomes between noon and midnight under field conditions [32] . However, these studies are based on bulk cells; we performed the first reef-building coral transcriptome analysis at the single-cell level.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Second, we classified the symbiotic cells into five groups based on clustering analysis and proposed a "symbiosis index" to characterize symbiotic cells. Little is known about coral cell types. Cells are briefly divided into two groups, epithelial-like ectoderm and endoderm cells (with or without zooxanthellae), referring to their embryological origins [15] . Symbiotic cells belong to the endoderm layer. No further classification of symbiotic cells has been established. We divided zooxanthellae coral symbiotic cells into five groups based on single-cell transcriptome sequencing results. Moreover, the symbiosis index can (Fig. 4A) . characterize symbiotic cells. For the holobiont of zooxanthellae and host coral, when genes of both species are highly expressed, the symbiosis index is high. Conversely, when either the algae or the coral symbiont is not in an active state, the symbiosis index will be low. Group G2 cells in our study had the highest symbiotic index, while group 1 had the lowest values (Fig. 4A) . The symbiosis index may be used as an indicator of the degree of symbiosis between coral and zooxanthellae. Further studies should evaluate this.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: In the clustering analysis, Group G2 was distantly related to group G1 (Fig. 4 B) . Also, Groups G1, G3, G4 and G5 had high intra-group similarity, unlike group G2, which included several minor subgroups (Fig. 3B and Fig. 4B ). Why is group G2 unique and what is the histological tissue source of these cells? We inferred that zooxanthellae may reside in the coenosarc and oral endoderm cells. Group G2 may belong to the coenosarc epithelial layer and cells in other groups may be derived from oral endoderm tissue. This inference is based on the spatial distribution; the coenosarc and oral side are exposed to sunlight, enabling zooxanthellae to undergo photosynthesis, with high variation. The coenosarc is a layer of epithelium-like tissue that connects all individual polyps to form a united coral colony [22] . Yet, direct evidence for zooxanthellae residing in the coenosarc is lacking. Further experiments should evaluate this.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Third, genes that are crucial for the symbiosis were identified. Despite the lack of gene annotation, we identified potential DEGs between highly and weakly symbiotic cells (Fig. 3 and Fig. 6 ). We identified the coral gene gfas1.m1.6761 [19] , whose expression was positively correlated with the symbiosis index (r = 0.76) (Fig. 4C ). Two metabolism-related genes, DAGLA and betaGlu [20, 21, 33] , were highly expressed in cells with a high symbiosis index. In coral cells, zooxanthellae genes PRPF19, ATRN, aAA-ATPase and SmicGene44833 exhibited changes in expression levels [22] [23] [24] .
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Taken together, this work provides a reference dataset, including symbiotic cell groups, the distribution of symbiotic cells, cell groupspecific gene markers, and a new index, the symbiosis index, for follow-up studies of gene expression in coral and zooxanthellae symbionts.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: The coral sample used in this study was collected from the South China Sea and maintained in artificial seawater at 35-36‰ salinity, pH 8.0, 23-25 • C in a 208-l aquarium equipped with a biological filtration system, illuminated by using a full-spectrum halide bulb on a 15 h/9 h light/dark photoperiod. It belongs to the reef-building coral Acropora based on morphology. A small colony was used for this study. A calciumfree artificial seawater cell dissociation protocol modified from Kopecky was used [16] . Briefly, 0.5-1.0 cm branches of new coral were detached from the parent colony with tweezers and placed in a 60 × 15 mm disposable Petri dish containing calcium-free seawater. The dish was shaken for 1 h at 60 rpms on a shaker at 25 • C. Then, the branches were washed with sterile PBS three times and disrupted with a sterile scalpel blade to obtain small pieces, which were then transferred into individual wells of a 6-well plate. Cultured cells were maintained in Dulbecco's modified Eagle medium (DMEM) supplemented with 1% antibiotics (penicillin-streptomycin). The plates were placed in a 24 • C incubator (5% CO 2 , 95% air), illuminated with a full-spectrum halide bulb on a 15 h/9 h light/dark photoperiod and checked daily for dissociated cells. After 2-3 days, cells were dissociated completely from the branches. Fig. 6 . DEGs between the symbiotic cells (Both) and the non-symbiotic cells (either "Coral only" or "Zoox only"). A, C: Volcano plots of DEGs between (A) the symbiotic ("Coral + Zoox", also "both") and "Coral only" cells and between (C) the symbiotic ("Coral + Zoox", also "both") and "Zoox only" cells. B, D: Plot of expression fold change values against the average expression level for DEGs.
body_text.section: Single coral cell isolation

body_text.text: Single-cell RNA sequencing was performed using the GEXSCOPE™ Single-Cell RNA Library Kit (Singleron Biotechnologies, New Haven, CT, USA). Briefly, after cell isolation, the single-cell suspension was loaded onto the microwell array and washed with PBS 2 times. Then the microbeads with unique cell barcode and unique molecular index (UMI) were loaded on the microchip. The diameter of each microwell and microbead is 45uM and 30uM respectively. The size of dissociated cell is about 9-13uM. The volume of one microwell can only accommodate one cell and one microbead, which ensure that each cell was coupled with only one bead. In a microfluidic chip, 60% microwells were filled with single cell when the concentration of diluted single cell suspension is about 10^5/mL. The other 40% are empty. The loading can be confirmed by microscope observing. For few microwells which were loaded with two cells, there will be no sufficient space for subsequent bead loading and will not confuse the result. After washing off the excess beads, cell lysis buffer was added to the microwell and the microchip was incubated at room temperature for cell lysis. The mRNAs of each cell were captured by the microbeads. The microbeads were then collected from the microchip and transferred to a PCR tube for reverse transcription and library construction. The cDNA was synthesized via reverse transcription and amplified by downstream PCR. The library was constructed by fragmenting the double-strained cDNA and the ligating adapters. The library was sequencing on the Illumina HiSeq X platform to obtain 150bp paired-end reads.
body_text.section: Single coral cell sequencing

body_text.text: A digital gene expression matrix was generated from raw sequence data using the Drop-seq core computational protocol [34] . Raw read1and read2-fastq files were merged into a uBAM file. From read 1, 5 ′ bases 1-12 and bases 13-20 with quality score of ≥10 were tagged as the cell barcode and UMI, respectively. The file was converted to a fastq file and aligned to the coral (Galaxea fascicularis) and zooxanthellae (Symbiodinium microadriaticum) genomes using STAR_2.4.0b with default parameters. The tagged cell barcode and UMI information were mapped again to the aligned reads. Only cells with at least 5 reads were included in further analyses. We obtained 9110 single cells and 10,335 genes. The cells were then divided into three types, "Coral+Zoox" (genes of both coral and zooxanthellae with a non-zero UMI) and "Coral only" and "Zoox only" (genes from either coral only or zoox only have non-zero UMI). Analyses were focused on "Coral+Zoox" cells.
body_text.section: Quality control and mapping of single-cell RNA-seq data

body_text.text: In clustering, due to the sparsity of the expression, only a proportion of genes and cells were included. For Coral+Zoox cells, we first chose the genes that were expressed in more than 1% of cells. Then, we chose the cells in which the number of expressed genes was beyond 5% of the total genes. This filtering approach resulted in an expression matrix of 73 genes and 1368 single cells.
body_text.section: Clustering of "Coral + Zoox" cells using Seurat

body_text.text: Using the R package Seurat (v.3.1.2) [35] , data normalization (LogNormalize), data feature scaling (scaling factor 10,000), imputation of dropped out values (RunALRA) [36] , variable gene detection (Find-VariableGenes, selection.method = 'vst'), PCA (RunPCA), and Louvain graph-based clustering (FindClusters, data dimensionality reduction using PCA, clustering resolution = 0.2) were performed. Five groups (clusters, G1-G5) were then identified. Marker genes were identified using the "FindAllMarkers" function (one-tailed Wilcoxon rank sum test, adjusted P = 0.01 [37] ).
body_text.section: Clustering of "Coral + Zoox" cells using Seurat

body_text.text: We defined a symbiosis index to evaluate symbiosis in the symbiont. Defining P Coral and P Zoox as the percentages of total genes that are expressed for coral and Zoox respectively, the symbiosis index was defined as log 10 (P Coral × P Zoox ). The basic idea is that if both species express genes actively, the symbiont will have a higher symbiosis index. The index was used to characterize the cell types identified in the clustering analysis.
body_text.section: Symbiosis index

body_text.text: The Monocle2 [38] [39] [40] package was employed to find the potential trajectory of cells classified as Coral+Zoox. The Seurat object for the Coral+ Zoox cells was inherited and used to construct input data for Monocle2, including "expression matrix," "phenoData," and "featur-eData." The dimensionality of the data was reduced to two by log normalization and the "DDRTree" method. Then, the order of cells was determined.
body_text.section: Pseudo-time trajectory analysis using Monocle2

body_text.text: Differentially expressed genes between the cell groups were identified by the Wilcoxon rank sum test with thresholds of a 2-fold change and adjusted P ≤ 0.00001.
body_text.section: Differentially expressed genes between groups

body_text.text: Owing to the lack of gene annotations for coral, homologous genes were obtained by searches against the NCBI database using BLAST. Gene annotation for zooxanthellae was obtained from the literature [37] .
body_text.section: Functional annotation of genes

back_matter.text: This work was financially supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (Grants 81827901, 81830053, 21327902 and 61850410528), the Fundamental Research Funds for the Central Universities.

Raw sequence data were deposited into the database of the National Genomics Data Center (NGDS, https://bigd.big.ac.cn/databases). The BioProject ID is PRJCA002567 (https://bigd.big.ac.cn/search?dbId=bio project&q=PRJCA002567). The whole data analysis procedure is described in supplementary file 1 (Supp.1).
The authors have declared no competing interests.
Supplementary data to this article can be found online at https://doi. org/10.1016/j.ygeno.2020.10.019.

FIGREF0.text: Microfluidic chip for single-cell sequencing. A. Microwell array containing the microfluidic chip for single-cell separation. B. Microbeads and coral cell loaded in the microwell array. C. Procedures for microfluidic chip-based single-cell separation and library construction.

FIGREF1.text: Symbiotic cells expressed genes of both species. A. Number of cells expressing at least one gene. Venn diagram indicates the number of genes in the three types of cells (Coral only, Zoox only and Coral + Zoox); Coral + Zoox represents symbiotic cells. B. Distribution of total UMI values for the three cell types. C. Percentage of single cells with expressed genes (x-axis) against the number of expressed genes (y-axis). D. Plot of average gene expression in three types of cells.

FIGREF2.text: Clustering analysis of symbiotic cells (Coral + Zoox) and DEGs in five cell groups. A. Clustering analysis of Coral + Zoox cells using Seurat; cells are clustered into five groups. B. Summary the top 30 DEGs in the five groups. C. Number of DEGs between groups in Coral + Zoox cells. D. Hierarchical clustering analysis of the five groups.

FIGREF3.text: Symbiosis index is an indicator of symbiotic cells. A. Cumulative distribution of cell counts for the symbiosis index in the five groups. B. Pearson correlation coefficient (r) for the relationship between gene expression in any two symbiotic cells (Coral + Zoox, n = 1368); C. Expression of gfas1.m1.6761 (ANKRD40) (y-axis) is positively correlated with the symbiosis index (x-axis); D. Volcano plot of the DEGs between cells with high and low symbiosis indices (symbiosis index cutoff = − 3.62); red indicates up-regulated genes in cells with a high symbiosis index. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.) Time-series analysis of the symbiotic cells. Pseudo-time trajectory for the symbiotic cells is shown. Colors indicate the groups identified in Fig. 3A. Symbiosis index: G2 > G5 > G3 > G4 > G1
